SENT.plain: We report the case of a 69-year-old woman with cerebral infarction in the left anterior cingulate cortex and corpus callosum
She showed hyperlexia, which was a distinctive reading phenomenon, as well as ambient echolalia
Clinical features also included complex disorders such as visual groping, compulsive manipulation of tools, and callosal disconnection syndrome
She read words written on the cover of a book and repeated words emanating from unrelated conversations around her or from hospital announcements
The combination of these two features due to a focal lesion has never been reported previously
The supplementary motor area may control the execution of established subroutines according to external and internal inputs

Hyperlexia as well as the compulsive manipulation of tools could be interpreted as faulty inhibition of preexisting essentially intact motor subroutines by damage to the anterior cingulate cortex reciprocally interconnected with the supplementary motor area
